Legal_Issue: Whether the Commission erred in refusing to exercise discretion under paragraph 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Application_Facts: Applicant delayed filing due to depression; medical evidence provided
Decision_Outcome: Commission refused to extend time limit; decision upheld on judicial review
Remedy_Requested: Extension of time limit to file human rights complaint
Grounds_for_Claim: Late filing due to mental disability (depression)
Assessment_Factor: Impact of depression on ability to file within time limit
Procedural_Issue: Timeliness of complaint filing and discretion to extend deadline
Credibility_Assessment: Medical evidence considered but not found sufficient to justify delay
Legal_Provision_Cited: Paragraph 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Application_Basis: Request for discretionary extension of time limit based on disability
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Commission's refusal to extend time limit
Governing_Rule: Commission may extend time if deemed appropriate under s. 41(1)(e)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Disability did not prevent timely filing according to investigator
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; Commission's decision upheld
Cause_Description: Applicant filed a human rights complaint late, citing depression as reason for delay
Evidence_Handling: Commission reviewed all materials including medical evidence
Evidence_Issues: Sufficiency of medical evidence to justify delay
Evidence_Assessment: Commission found no barrier to filing despite depression
Decision_Rationale: Decision not patently unreasonable; discretion appropriately exercised
Evidentiary_Issues: Medical evidence did not establish inability to file on time
